Concentration name: Financial Accounting/Auditing, Taxation, Accounting Information Systems
description: The Master of Accountancy (MAcc) program is a 30-credit hour graduate program designed for students with an undergraduate degree in accounting. The program prepares students for a variety of career opportunities in public accounting, industry, government and not-for-profit organizations. It provides students with deeper and broader skills in the fields of accounting and business than is possible in the undergraduate program. The MAcc program is designed to fulfill the educational requirements to be a licensed Certified Public Accountant (CPA) in Kansas and most other jurisdictions.
Accreditation status: The college is accredited by the Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business (AACSB). The Department of Accounting also holds separate AACSB accreditation, a distinction held by less than 2 percent of business schools worldwide.

Program name: Adult-Gerontology Acute Care Nurse Practitioner Cert

description: The adult-gerontology acute care nurse practitioner master's program at Kansas State University prepares registered nurses for advanced practice nursing roles providing care to adults of all ages with complex, acute and chronic health conditions. Graduates of this program will be eligible to sit for the Adult-Gerontology Acute Care Nurse Practitioner (AGACNP) national certification exam. The curriculum is developed in accordance with the American Association of Colleges of Nursing (AACN) Essentials of Master's Education in Nursing and the National Organization of Nurse Practitioner Faculties (NONPF) Nurse Practitioner Core Competencies. Our program offers small class sizes, allowing students a greater opportunity for discussion, sharing and support. Students progress through the curriculum with the same group of peers, which creates a collaborative learning community.
Accreditation status: The master's degree program in nursing at Kansas State University is accredited by the Commission on Collegiate Nursing Education, 655 K Street NW, Suite 750, Washington, DC 20001, 202-887-6791.
Program name: Adult-Gerontology Acute Care Nurse Practitioner MSN

description: The Adult-Gerontology Primary Care Nurse Practitioner graduate certificate provides knowledge and experiences for graduates to provide primary care to the entire spectrum of adults, including young adults, adults, and older adults. The program is an online program offered through K-State's Global Campus. The coursework meets the educational requirements for graduates to take the national certification exam through the American Nurses Credentialing Center (ANCC) or the American Association of Nurse Practitioners (AANP). The program is only available to those who have already completed a graduate degree in nursing (MSN or DNP). It is not available to those who wish to combine with a graduate degree. The program consists of 25 credit hours. Students will complete 600 clinical hours as part of their studies.
Accreditation status: The Master of Science in Nursing program at Kansas State University is accredited by the Commission on Collegiate Nursing Education (http://www.ccneaccreditation.org).
Program name: Adult-Gerontology Primary Care Nurse Practitioner Cert

description:
The Adult-Gerontology Primary care Nurse Practitioner (AGPCNP) specialty in the MSN program prepares advanced practice nurses to manage the health of individuals from adolescence through adulthood and the end of life. The focus of the AGPCNP is to provide primary health care to adults with an emphasis on health promotion, disease prevention, and the management of acute and chronic health conditions. Graduates of this specialty are prepared to take the national certification exam and to be licensed in Kansas as an advanced practice registered nurse (APRN). The curriculum requires 47 credit hours of coursework and at least 600 clinical hours.

Upon completion of the adult-gerontology primary care nurse practitioner specialty, the graduate will be able to:

1. Synthesize knowledge from nursing and other disciplines to provide advanced nursing care to diverse populations.
2. Provide advanced nursing care to individuals, families and communities.
3. Incorporate teaching and learning principles in the provision of advanced nursing care.
4. Evaluate nursing practice outcomes.
5. Assume a leadership role in the development of professional nursing.
6. Disseminate research findings through scholarly activities.
7. Advocate for professional nursing and for health in the political and policy arenas.
8. Demonstrate competence in an advanced nursing role.
Accreditation status: The baccalaureate degree program in nursing, master’s degree program in nursing, and Doctor of Nursing Practice program at Kansas State University are accredited by the Commission on Collegiate Nursing Education (http://www.ccneaccreditation.org).
Program name: Adult-Gerontology Primary Care Nurse Practitioner MSN

description: The M.A. in mass communication is a 30-hour program designed for students who want to develop a deeper and more sophisticated understanding of mass communication and for those who wish to pursue a Ph.D. We offer thesis and non-thesis options. Most M.A. students choose the non-thesis option, which includes a professional track for those who have at least two years of professional experience in media and communication and a coursework option for those with less than two years of experience. The professional track requires 30 hours of graduate-level coursework and successful completion of a professional project. The coursework option requires 30 hours of coursework and successful completion of a comprehensive exam. Both options require a minimum of 21 hours in the school and 12 hours at the 800-900 level. The thesis option requires 30 hours, including six hours of thesis research, and successful completion of an oral defense of the thesis.
Accreditation status: Our graduate program is part of the only accredited journalism and mass communication program in Kansas. The Accrediting Council on Education in Journalism and Mass Communications (ACEJMC) is the agency responsible for the evaluation of professional journalism and mass communications programs in colleges and universities.

description:
Our Anthropology graduate program offers both a Master of Arts (M.A.) and a Ph.D. in anthropology. We also offer a Graduate Certificate in the anthropology of global health and development.

Our faculty have expertise in a wide variety of topics and world areas and have specialized knowledge in four subfields: archaeology, biological anthropology, linguistic anthropology, and sociocultural anthropology. Our research emphases include the anthropology of health, Indigenous studies, and political and environmental anthropology.

Students work closely with their faculty mentors to develop research projects and gain teaching experience. We are committed to an anthropology that matters and welcome students interested in applied, activist, and engaged work. We are a small but dynamic and highly collaborative program and offer excellent training and numerous opportunities for student professionalization.

Biological anthropology is the study of humans from a biological perspective. At its core, biological anthropology seeks to understand what makes humans a unique species by examining our evolutionary history and our modern biological diversity. Applied biological anthropology takes the theories and methods of biological anthropology and applies them to real-world problems. At K-State, we specialize in forensic anthropology (the application of skeletal biology to medicolegal death investigations) and paleo-skeletal biology/bioarchaeology (the study of human skeletons from archaeological sites). This program offers hands-on training in our biological anthropology laboratories, and students may elect to conduct original research with a faculty mentor to fulfill their research portfolio requirement. The M.A. program provides the skills and background necessary for a variety of careers including forensic death investigation, cultural resource management, and museum curation, or for continuing education in a Ph.D. program.

The Ed.D. in applied learning sciences is a professional practice doctorate with a focus on solving problems of practice within formal and informal learning environments. This 60-credit hour online degree will prepare students to be able to apply cutting-edge research to real-world learning problems; develop as leaders in a variety of educational settings; conduct rigorous, applied research to inform practice; communicate effectively with a variety of audiences; and understand, evaluate, and use a variety of research methods. This degree program is a part of the Great Plains Interactive Distance Education Alliance (Great Plains IDEA). The coursework is all offered online.

The doctorate in curriculum and instruction with a specialization in applied learning sciences is a 90-credit hour program designed for working education professionals who want to grow in their ability to design, implement and evaluate learning experiences. Learning sciences is an interdisciplinary field that draws upon research in education, cognitive science, developmental and social psychology, anthropology, sociology, and computer science. The Ed.D. will equip you to make evidence-based decisions to improve learning environments for all learners, including those in K-12 classrooms, higher education, workplace training and informal settings such as museums or after-school programs. All courses are delivered online through a combination of synchronous (set meeting times in the evenings) and asynchronous (anytime) formats, enabling you to earn your degree without sacrificing your professional and personal responsibilities.
Accreditation status: The K-State College of Education is accredited by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP) and the Kansas State Department of Education.

description:
The applied physiology graduate program provides students with the advanced knowledge and skills necessary to work as a professional in adult fitness, cardiac rehabilitation, corporate wellness and other related clinical or research fields. Students will become familiar with the concepts underlying the physiological responses to exercise. Coursework is designed to develop practical skills that can be used to meet requirements for certifications offered by the American College of Sports Medicine (ACSM). Upon completion of their degree, students should be able to:
Describe the physiological responses to exercise.
Discuss the role of exercise in health and disease.
Describe appropriate exercise prescriptions for different populations.
Administer and interpret exercise tests.
Design and conduct research related to exercise.

The Master of Professional Studies (M.P.S.) in Applied Remote Sensing is designed to provide graduate-level training in the theory and application of remote sensing science for students who have a background in environmental science, geography, geology, agriculture, natural resources, or a related field. The 30 credit-hour M.P.S. in Applied Remote Sensing is a non-thesis, online program which is structured to be flexible enough for both working professionals and traditional students to be successful.

The curriculum is built on a foundation of four core courses, totaling 15 credit hours, which provide students with a solid background in remote sensing and geospatial data analysis. Students will then choose 15 credit hours of elective courses to focus on an applied area of remote sensing, which culminates in a final capstone experience. All of the courses in the M.P.S. in Applied Remote Sensing are taught by faculty in the Department of Geography and Geospatial Sciences.

The Master of Professional Studies in Aquaculture is an online, non-thesis degree program offered by the Department of Horticulture and Natural Resources. The program provides students the opportunity to increase their understanding of the scientific principles and management applications necessary for a successful aquaculture venture. The MPS in Aquaculture provides an opportunity for students to advance their education while also preparing them for a career as an aquaculture professional.

Concentration name: Building structural systems, Building mechanical systems, Building electrical power distribution systems, Lighting design
description:
The Master of Science in Architectural Engineering (MSAE) is an advanced degree program that provides students with the enhanced engineering and scientific knowledge necessary to design, construct and operate the next generation of high performance buildings. Graduate study in architectural engineering is closely allied to our extensive research and teaching facilities for building systems.

The graduate program in architectural engineering offers students the opportunity to study in the following areas of specialization: building structural systems; building mechanical systems; building electrical power distribution systems; and lighting design. The graduate program also supports study in the general area of building systems, with particular emphasis on building energy systems and analysis, building fenestration systems, advanced control systems, and acoustics and noise control.

Graduate students in our program have outstanding opportunities to conduct research in our world-class facilities. This research focuses on critical areas that are vital to our nation’s future: sustainable energy and building science. These studies are conducted within K-State’s new engineering complex, which includes more than 108,000 square feet of instructional, research and office space. This facility provides an exceptional learning environment for both undergraduate and graduate students.

The Classical Architecture Certificate provides students with a foundational knowledge of the principles of classical architecture as a living language of design. Open to all students in the College of Architecture, Planning and Design, the program complements a professional design education and offers a credential that prepares students to engage with the vibrant and growing world of contemporary classical design.

The Artist Development undergraduate certificate provides students with the fundamental building blocks of acting, directing, design, and script analysis. The certificate will focus on the development of foundational artistic skills for theatre artists. Through an array of theatre practice courses, students will strengthen their skills and understanding of theatre creation. This certificate will be an attractive option for students who are not majoring in theatre but want to hone their skills as a performing artist. This certificate will also appeal to the student who wishes to complete a course of study which may benefit them in an array of potential career paths (e.g. business, marketing, law) while concurrently satisfying their K-State 8 requirements. Students will also learn skills in communication, problem solving and creative expression. The undergraduate certificate in Artist Development will require 12 credit hours, all of which will be delivered online. This certificate is designed to give K-State students a path to explore theatre practice without having to major or minor in theatre.

Arts leadership is the capacity to create an environment where artists, arts organizations, audiences, and communities can thrive. Students in this program will develop a personal philosophy of arts leadership, an understanding of leadership styles and theories, management skills, a greater understanding of cultural policy and advocacy, and an expanded awareness of arts programming. The arts leadership certificate is intended for individuals who have an interest in working in arts administration or for artists who would like to start their own non-profit. The certificate may be used to enhance career potential, as a stand-alone graduate credential, or as an area of emphasis for a graduate degree.

The online arts management and leadership graduate certificate from Kansas State University will equip you with the essential skills to excel in the vibrant arts and culture industry. This certificate is ideal for professionals currently working in the field and individuals looking to change careers.

The curriculum is designed to give you a strong foundation in key areas such as fundraising, marketing, financial management and organizational leadership within the arts sector. Through hands-on learning experiences and expert instruction from seasoned professionals, you’ll gain practical knowledge and strategic insights to navigate the complexities of managing arts organizations.

Whether you aspire to lead a theater company, manage a museum, or launch your own creative enterprise, this certificate will empower you to make a meaningful impact in the world of arts and culture.

The graduate certificate in Arts Presenting Fundamentals provides students with a foundational curriculum in arts presenting. The graduate certificate allows those who are new to the field, and/or have not yet earned an MA, with a course of study which offers professional context and foundational knowledge of the arts presenting field. This certificate prepares students for entry-level positions in the arts presenting field.

The mission of the Master of Science in Athletic Training program at Kansas State University is to provide a comprehensive and progressive educational and clinical foundation to prepare students for a career in athletic training. Our program is committed to a student-centered educational environment that prepares graduates for a successful career in a variety of clinical settings and professional endeavors. Students are challenged in the classroom and clinical setting to apply knowledge and become critical thinkers and evidence-based practitioners. Graduates of the program are expected to be professionals and leaders within the athletic training community who act in a legal and ethical manner and place the welfare of the patient first.
Accreditation status: The athletic training program at Kansas State University is accredited by the Commission on Accreditation of Athletic Training Education (CAATE). The program is currently on probation. Please see our accreditation page for more details.

description: The graduate program in atmospheric sciences is designed to train students for professional careers in research, education and service. The program is flexible and may be adapted to meet the needs of students with undergraduate preparation in meteorology, physics, chemistry, mathematics, computer science or engineering. The program requires a student to complete an original research project, documented in a formal thesis, and pass an oral defense of the thesis.

The Professional Science Master's (P.S.M.) program at Kansas State University is an innovative graduate degree designed to allow students to pursue advanced training in science, while simultaneously developing highly-valued business skills. A P.S.M. degree prepares graduates for careers in business, government, and non-profit organizations. The environmental geoscience track is administered through the Department of Geography and Geospatial Sciences. This track prepares students for careers in the high-demand fields of water resources, environmental geology, atmospheric sciences, geographic information systems, and remote sensing. The curriculum provides a strong foundation in both the theory and application of these fields, while the professional skills component of the curriculum prepares graduates for careers as practicing scientists in the private and public sectors.

The graduate program in atmospheric sciences provides a broad background in the fundamental principles of atmospheric dynamics, synoptic meteorology, mesoscale meteorology, boundary-layer meteorology, and agricultural meteorology. The faculty in the department consists of eight full-time graduate faculty and one adjunct professor who hold degrees in atmospheric science and have research experience in a wide range of specialties including severe storms, mesoscale meteorology, climate variability, agricultural meteorology, biometeorology, boundary-layer meteorology, and air pollution meteorology.

The Department of Biochemistry and Molecular Biophysics offers graduate programs leading to the Master of Science and the Doctor of Philosophy degrees in biochemistry and molecular biophysics. The department also participates in the interdepartmental Master of Science and Doctor of Philosophy degree programs in genetics and the Master of Public Health degree program. The major work for all these programs may be in any of the areas in which the graduate faculty are active. These include plant biochemistry and molecular biology, protein structure and function, cell biology, enzymology, proteomics and mass spectrometry, membrane protein biology and biophysics, molecular genetics, bioinformatics, immunochemistry, virology and cancer research. Students may pursue graduate work in either biochemistry and molecular biology (MS, PhD) or molecular biophysics (PhD).

The Department of Biochemistry and Molecular Biophysics offers graduate programs leading to the Master of Science (non-thesis) and Doctor of Philosophy degrees. Graduate study is directed toward developing a broad understanding of the theory and practice of modern biochemistry and molecular biology and providing training in biochemical research. Areas of research emphasis within the department are broad and include protein structure and function, enzymology, cell and developmental biology, molecular genetics, proteomics, cancer biology, virology, immunology, neuroscience, and bioinformatics. The department is a participant in interdisciplinary graduate degree programs in genetics and molecular, cellular, and developmental biology.

The graduate programs are housed in Chalmers Hall and Burt Hall. Research facilities are excellent and include a wide range of state-of-the-art instrumentation for research in biochemistry and molecular biology. Additional university facilities available for departmental research include those for DNA and protein sequencing and synthesis, mass spectrometry, NMR, X-ray crystallography, confocal and electron microscopy, and transgenic and knockout mice.

Students in the doctoral program are supported by graduate research or teaching assistantships or by fellowships. All students in the Ph.D. program are required to participate in the department’s teaching program. All students in good standing receive a full tuition waiver.

The doctoral program includes formal coursework, seminars, and original laboratory research. All entering graduate students do research rotations in the laboratories of three faculty members during their first year. By the end of the first year, the student selects a major professor and a supervisory committee. Before the end of the third year of study, the doctoral candidate must pass a preliminary oral examination covering the student’s proposed dissertation research and related areas of biochemistry and molecular biology. The Ph.D. degree is awarded after the candidate has successfully completed the program of study, presented a public seminar, and passed a final oral defense of the dissertation, as well as other requirements for the degree.

The Department of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology offers a doctorate program in biochemistry and molecular biology for working professionals that is completed almost entirely online. This innovative program is designed to serve the needs of individuals who are employed in the public and private sectors (e.g., industry, government and education) and whose careers require advanced training in biochemistry and molecular biology. The executive Ph.D. is a non-thesis, non-research degree. The program is offered via distance education with only a one-week, on-campus session required each summer. Most students complete the program in four to five years.
Program name: Biochemistry and Molecular Biology Executive PhD Online

Concentration name: Ecology and evolutionary biology, Cellular and molecular biology and genetics, Physiological biology, Microbiology
description: The Division of Biology at Kansas State University offers a vibrant and supportive environment for graduate students. We offer a Master of Science (M.S.) and Doctor of Philosophy (Ph.D.) in Biology. Graduate students have the opportunity to work with over 35 faculty members in four broad areas of emphasis: ecology and evolutionary biology, cellular and molecular biology and genetics, physiological biology, and microbiology. Many of our faculty also participate in interdisciplinary graduate degree programs, such as Genetics, Molecular, Cellular, and Developmental Biology (MCDV), and Pathobiology. The Division of Biology has an excellent record of training graduate students who are highly competitive and successful in a wide variety of careers in academia, government, and industry.

The PhD degree in biology is designed to develop independent investigators with a broad knowledge of biological sciences and expertise in a research area that culminates in a dissertation. Students may choose to conduct research in any of the primary research areas represented in the division. In consultation with the supervisory committee, a student develops a program of study that includes a minimum of 90 graduate credit hours. The supervisory committee determines whether a student’s prior work is acceptable for graduate credit. A typical PhD program will include formal coursework, research, dissertation, teaching, and seminars. Students will conduct research under the direction of a major professor within the Division of Biology. All students are required to participate in teaching, typically as a graduate teaching assistant.

The Master of Science (MS) degree in Biomedical Engineering (BME) at Kansas State University is an interdisciplinary program administered by the College of Engineering and offered collaboratively by the departments of Biological and Agricultural Engineering, Chemical Engineering, Electrical and Computer Engineering, and Mechanical and Nuclear Engineering. The goal of the MS BME is to educate engineers who can apply engineering principles to problems in medicine and biology and to understand and use them to improve human health. Students in the BME MS program must complete a minimum of 30 credit hours and choose one of the three emphasis areas: biomaterials and tissue engineering; biomedical instrumentation, sensors and signal processing; or biomechanics.

The biomedical engineering (BME) Ph.D. is an interdisciplinary graduate degree program jointly administered by the College of Engineering and the College of Veterinary Medicine. The BME Ph.D. program aims to prepare students for independent research careers in biomedical engineering in academia, industry or government.

Students in the BME Ph.D. program select a research focus area from the following:

Biomaterials and Tissue Engineering
Biomechanics
Biomedical Signal Processing and Instrumentation
Students are directly admitted to the research group of a BME faculty member where they will perform BME research and gain teaching and mentoring experiences as part of their Ph.D. training. Coursework requirements depend on the undergraduate degree and background of each student.
